articles.headline: Tibetan Lama Faces Scrutiny and Suspicion in India
articles.snippet: One of Tibetan Buddhism’s most revered incarnate lamas has seen his quest for a monastery unexpectedly set off a national furor, fanned by Indian media.
articles.abstract: One of Tibetan Buddhism’s most revered incarnate lamas has seen his quest for a monastery unexpectedly set off a national furor, fanned by Indian media.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHARAMSALA, India  His daring escape from Tibet seemed out of a movie. Then only 14, Ogyen Trinley Dorje was one of Tibetan Buddhism’s most revered incarnate lamas, and his journey through the icy passes of the Himalayas was viewed as a major embarrassment for China. The youth arrived in India in early 2000 to a euphoric greeting from Tibetan exiles.

articles.headline: In Egypt, U.S. Weighs Push for Change With Stability
articles.snippet: Lacking better options, the United States is encouraging Vice President Omar Suleiman to make changes the government has resisted for years.
articles.abstract: Lacking better options, the United States is encouraging Vice President Omar Suleiman to make changes the government has resisted for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Omar Suleiman of Egypt says he does not think it is time to lift the 30-year-old emergency law that has been used to suppress and imprison opposition leaders. He does not think President Hosni Mubarak needs to resign before his term ends in September. And he does not think his country is yet ready for democracy.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: AOL’s Bet on Another Makeover
articles.snippet: In buying the liberal news commentary site The Huffington Post, AOL is trying to meld its disparate content sites, attract traffic and increase advertising revenue.
articles.abstract: In buying the liberal news commentary site The Huffington Post, AOL is trying to meld its disparate content sites, attract traffic and increase advertising revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — AOL is trying to remake itself, yet again.

articles.headline: Big Personality and Behind-the-Scenes Executive Prove a Top Media Team
articles.snippet: Arianna Huffington was the company’s face, but just as essential was the sophisticated technology and careful brand management of Kenneth Lerer.
articles.abstract: Arianna Huffington was the company’s face, but just as essential was the sophisticated technology and careful brand management of Kenneth Lerer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Huffington Post broke into public consciousness based on its namesake and Arianna Huffington’s A-list Rolodex, but it never would have merited a $315 million payday if those gilded elements had not been married to sophisticated technology and careful brand management.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: A Seer on Banks Raises a Furor on Bonds
articles.snippet: Meredith Whitney gained attention for her warning about bank stocks in 2007, but her star has been somewhat tarnished by her prediction of a calamity in municipal bonds.
articles.abstract: Meredith Whitney gained attention for her warning about bank stocks in 2007, but her star has been somewhat tarnished by her prediction of a calamity in municipal bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: If one stock-picker emerged intact from the wreckage of the financial crisis, it was Meredith Whitney. With a prescient warning about bank stocks in 2007  as well as a gift for the perfect sound bite  she became a media darling, celebrated in a Fortune cover article and in frequent television appearances as a market seer.

articles.headline: As Egypt Protest Swells, U.S. Sends Specific Demands
articles.snippet: In one of the largest protests yet, Egyptians loudly rejected the government’s approach to change.
articles.abstract: In one of the largest protests yet, Egyptians loudly rejected the government’s approach to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Pressure intensified on President Hosni Mubarak’s government as the largest crowd of protesters in two weeks flooded Cairo’s streets on Tuesday and the United States delivered its most specific demands yet, urging swift steps toward democracy.
